componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Vijay Bhagavath with Deutsche Bank Securities.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Chuck, my question is around we had done independent checks and had noted near-term weakness in U.S. Enterprise. Like to get your qualitative color. I know you work very closely with the sales teams and also with some of your bigger customers.
componenttext: So Chuck, my question is around we had done independent checks and had noted near-term weakness in U.S. Enterprise. Like to get your qualitative color. I know you work very closely with the sales teams and also with some of your bigger customers.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Vijay, we are having a hard time hearing you. Could you speak a little louder?
componenttext: Vijay, we are having a hard time hearing you. Could you speak a little louder?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think my question was around independent checks with that channel board noted near-term order weakness, U.S. Enterprise in particular. Could you give us qualitative color from your end? Is it just endemic weakness, customer wishes putting out because th
componenttext: I think my question was around independent checks with that channel board noted near-term order weakness, U.S. Enterprise in particular. Could you give us qualitative color from your end? Is it just endemic weakness, customer wishes putting out because they're all in your company metals are weak like the U.S. industrials? Or is it relating to any indecision around migration to public cloud? Like to get your commentary on the weakness you noted in the enterprise.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Vijay, and tell Brian hello when you see them. So relative to the enterprise, we actually are very comfortable with the situation in the U.S. We did see weakness, particularly outside the United States. And particularly in Asia Pacific, we sa
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Vijay, and tell Brian hello when you see them. So relative to the enterprise, we actually are very comfortable with the situation in the U.S. We did see weakness, particularly outside the United States. And particularly in Asia Pacific, we saw weakness in Canada as well as Latin America. And I don't -- we didn't see any impact that was different this quarter from public cloud. We think our customers are moving to hybrid cloud environment, which I think is indicative of the $0.5 billion that we did in our data next-generation data center switching portfolio this quarter. And so we're actually very comfortable with our portfolio. If you think about our U.S. commercial business and then our global commercial business, our U.S. commercial business was up 12%. And it is a good proxy of how our portfolio is playing in that space. And we firmly believe that if there was a significant difference in the transition of workloads to public cloud, we would sit there first. So we're very comfortable with our Enterprise strategy right now.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simona Jankowski from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simona Jankowski from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I wanted to ask you a couple of questions on margins. So first, they came in pretty strong in the quarter even though routing was weaker. And that tends to be a higher-margin product line. So just curious what drove the upside. And the bigger questio
componenttext: Yes. I wanted to ask you a couple of questions on margins. So first, they came in pretty strong in the quarter even though routing was weaker. And that tends to be a higher-margin product line. So just curious what drove the upside. And the bigger question related to that, Chuck, is if you've had margins exceeding expectations for 2 [ph] quarters now. And in the meantime, your growth is decelerating quite a bit here. Some that is driven by FX and international issues. Do you feel like you're dialing that equation sufficiently in the direction of revenue growth versus margin preservation?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Simona, it's a very good question. Thank you. I'm going to give a couple of comments, and then I'm going to ask last Kelly to chime in. First of all, I think that we talked about -- I think it's well-documented that there are some currency issues aro
componenttext: Yes, Simona, it's a very good question. Thank you. I'm going to give a couple of comments, and then I'm going to ask last Kelly to chime in. First of all, I think that we talked about -- I think it's well-documented that there are some currency issues around the world. And I think our teams have done an incredible job of managing that. And we did see our gross margins, non-GAAP gross margins very strong this quarter. So we constantly look at the balance of investment in areas, and we're actively investing in those areas that are providing growth for us like security and in certain countries and in our Meraki portfolio. But it's something that we'll continue to look at. Kelly, comments on gross margins?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say, just add to that, Simona, this is a big focus for us and all of our business units. But if you look at what you see in our Q, we have our typical range. Our pricing has been holding in our typical range, which is a good sign. When we saw the
componenttext: Yes, I'd say, just add to that, Simona, this is a big focus for us and all of our business units. But if you look at what you see in our Q, we have our typical range. Our pricing has been holding in our typical range, which is a good sign. When we saw the upside from a year-over-year perspective here, we just had a really, really strong productivity this quarter in gross margin on the product side that drove a lot of the benefit. And again, it's what the engineering teams are working on. It's what supply chain is driving. So it's part of what we're driving to offset the competitive pressures that we have naturally in the tech space. So I think it's definitely a good execution by the teams. The way that we make sure also that we're not doing a trade-off, like you mentioned, because we are driving for growth and profits, is we look at things like when rates, we look at things like obviously market share. So we're making sure we're making the right trade-offs to get the wins that we want and balancing that because this is all about growth as well as profits.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Sue with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Sue with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Looking at a high level, the company's gone through many rounds of layoffs and reorgs. And we see this impacts some to company such as IBM and HP. Having said that, do you feel that we should see some accelerated innovation coming out of Cisco over the ne
componenttext: Looking at a high level, the company's gone through many rounds of layoffs and reorgs. And we see this impacts some to company such as IBM and HP. Having said that, do you feel that we should see some accelerated innovation coming out of Cisco over the next -- as we look towards the back half? Product catalyst, for example, pipeline of innovation, you could give us those positive things to look for in the second half?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark, that's a great question. I actually thank you very much for asking it. As I said in my opening comments, we have -- in our engineering organization. we've really focused on smaller agile teams that are moving more quickly. You're going to see s
componenttext: Yes, Mark, that's a great question. I actually thank you very much for asking it. As I said in my opening comments, we have -- in our engineering organization. we've really focused on smaller agile teams that are moving more quickly. You're going to see some innovation, as I said, that's going to come out next week. You're going to see a nice, steady stream of new products in the market. In fact, one of the comments I made was that I am -- I feel like we're very well-positioned for the second half. And that's one of the key reasons is we have a good of a new product pipeline. So I think you will be very pleased with the innovation that comes out over the next few months.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jim Suva of Citigroup Global Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jim Suva of Citigroup Global Markets.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question is, I believe, unless my memory is wrong, that you had a kind of long-term organic sales growth rate of about 3% to 6%. I think that might have been the case. And the outlook now is kind of 0% to 2%. Can you help us understand or quantify, is
componenttext: My question is, I believe, unless my memory is wrong, that you had a kind of long-term organic sales growth rate of about 3% to 6%. I think that might have been the case. And the outlook now is kind of 0% to 2%. Can you help us understand or quantify, is some of this due to FX? And how much? And it looks like probably service providers also driving that down. So maybe Ericsson, new partnership you have can help out at some point. And just kind of help us bridge the gap of 0% to 2% outlook for the next quarter versus your long-term goal of 3% to 6%. .

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll start addressing that question. I'll hand it over to Chuck on the Ericsson question. So from an FX perspective, us, like every other multinationals, are feeling the impact of the strength of the U.S. dollar. For us, it's a little more difficult to
componenttext: So I'll start addressing that question. I'll hand it over to Chuck on the Ericsson question. So from an FX perspective, us, like every other multinationals, are feeling the impact of the strength of the U.S. dollar. For us, it's a little more difficult to quantify because we sell 90% of our products in U.S. dollars. But I can tell you, when I look at the countries that we do sell in local currency, which for us is like Australia, Canada, parts of Japan, for those countries alone where I can't quantify, it was almost 2 points of just pure translation on our top line growth. So for the rest of our business that's sold outside the U.S., there is certainly impact. It's just hard for us to quantify it directly. So again, we try to see if we're getting less -- if the demand is under pressure by the number of deals that we have in the pipeline or things along those lines as well as if we see pressure from our sales teams to discount heavily. So what I'd say is yes, us like every other multi-multinational is feeling the impact of the strength of the U.S. dollar. But I think our sales teams are executing extremely well through that and being able to sell the value of our solutions just like that. For sure, identified 2 points in just because he said we have and there's I'm sure more 3 to 4 or more even besides it that we can't put our finger on.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Jim, just a couple of comments. You mentioned the 0% to 2%, that's our guidance for Q2. And I think the 3% to 6% you mentioned is what Kelly presented as long-term model at the last financial analyst conference. On the SP side, I'll just make a couple
componenttext: And Jim, just a couple of comments. You mentioned the 0% to 2%, that's our guidance for Q2. And I think the 3% to 6% you mentioned is what Kelly presented as long-term model at the last financial analyst conference. On the SP side, I'll just make a couple of comments that we're very pleased with our performance there. We've had the second quarter of growth, teams are executing very well. And you're right, the partnership that we announced with Ericsson really leverages their strength in radio, in OSS BSS network management and inside SB as well as a scale from a services perspective around the world. And then you combine that with our strength in IP and data center and networking and security, we think that it's a good combination. Our customers believe that are actually quite pleased with the partnership that we put together.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Tal Liani with Bank of America Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Tal Liani with Bank of America Securities.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions, and I'll ask them. Hopefully you can answer at least a part of the second one. Switching was very weak the past few quarters on a sequential basis. It was sub-seasonal last quarter also, but this quarter was very strong. And I'm wantin
componenttext: I have 2 questions, and I'll ask them. Hopefully you can answer at least a part of the second one. Switching was very weak the past few quarters on a sequential basis. It was sub-seasonal last quarter also, but this quarter was very strong. And I'm wanting if you can give a little bit of color on what's going right and what's going wrong. And how sustainable the strength in switching? And the second question, which is related but not related, your service growth is below your product growth if I sum up the last 4 quarters. And you mentioned it a little bit at the beginning of your opening comments. So if you can just clarify why is it happening.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Tal, let me take the first one, and then I'll let Kelly go into some of the numbers. The switching, I think the biggest thing that I've talked about as over the last few months is that we've been going through this transition in the next-generation dat
componenttext: So Tal, let me take the first one, and then I'll let Kelly go into some of the numbers. The switching, I think the biggest thing that I've talked about as over the last few months is that we've been going through this transition in the next-generation data center. If you think about what happens in the data center as you've got the traditional data center switching architecture, and then you've got our computer platforms that we sell and then we have the next-generation data center switching architecture. And the historical architecture, we know, has been declining as customers transition. Our UCS business was up 24% this quarter, so we're very pleased with those results. And then if you look at the next-generation data center, that's the business that we said eclipsed $0.5 billion this quarter growing at 140%. So what I've said about our switching business is that in the second half of the year, we expect the inflection point between the next-generation volume and the historical generation to sort of -- we expect to hit that inflection point. I think you're seeing the next-generation switching in the data center continued to contribute to some of the improvement that you saw. And frankly, we've also had some reasonable performance in the campus. And on the services, on the -- any other comment on switching and then the services, Kelly?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, I think you hit it right on, on switching. And on services, yes, it was up 1%, which is obviously on the lower end of what we were looking for. And it's driven by a couple of things, and we talked about this before. It is isolated largely to our
componenttext: Yes, no, I think you hit it right on, on switching. And on services, yes, it was up 1%, which is obviously on the lower end of what we were looking for. And it's driven by a couple of things, and we talked about this before. It is isolated largely to our -- within service revenue, the Service Provider segment, within there. So the Service Provider has been a headwind been for us up until the last quarter or so. So the model typically, it takes longer for services to feel the impact when the product side was down. Same way, it takes a little bit longer, a few quarters before they start to see it when the section, the product side comes up. So we are seeing some of that as well is just the Service Provider segment in general. They're going through a lot of transition as well. So that's a tough segment for us. But it's largely isolated for that. The only other piece I'll add to that is we are feeling very good about the outlook in services. If you look at our services deferred revenue, that went up 7% year-over-year this quarter, which is $600-plus million, almost $700 million. And that's the strongest growth we've seen on that metric for a while. So we feel good about more multi-year deals coming in and future revenue coming from that. But clearly, this quarter, at 1%, it's on the low end and isolated in the Service Provider section.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pierre Ferragu with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pierre Ferragu with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd like to come back on your gross margin. So you're up more than 1 point sequentially, 1 point above what you had guided for. And at the same time, so you have subscription and licensing deferred revenues are up [indiscernible] I think 36% [ph]. So my f
componenttext: I'd like to come back on your gross margin. So you're up more than 1 point sequentially, 1 point above what you had guided for. And at the same time, so you have subscription and licensing deferred revenues are up [indiscernible] I think 36% [ph]. So my first question would be, could you give us a bit of breakout of what are the important drivers of [indiscernible] price in gross margin? And then my second question is when I look at your guidance for next quarter, so you guide 63% -- 62% to 63%. This is going to ex some that book of business. So from like a 36% [ph] of 33% [ph] level this quarter, it almost feels like not a very challenging guidance.  so I might missing maybe some kind of sequential headwinds on that number.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay. Thanks. That's a great question. So first, to your last point, we definitely have seasonality in our gross margin. If you look back, typically, Q2 and Q4 have lower gross margins, driven by our mix. So they're very, very big quarters for us o
componenttext: Right. Okay. Thanks. That's a great question. So first, to your last point, we definitely have seasonality in our gross margin. If you look back, typically, Q2 and Q4 have lower gross margins, driven by our mix. So they're very, very big quarters for us on the UCSF, on our data center of us, that's a big part of what's driving it. And conversely, Q2 and Q4 are typically higher. Now I would say again, again, we had very, very good execution across the board on gross margins and again, driven by the performance by the team on the productivity side. So again, that will continue to help. When I go to Q2 guidance, you picked right up on it. Q1 still had the set-top box business in it. In my guidance for Q2, I completely removed the set-top box business, which is why it's up a full point of our typical guidance of 61% to 62%. We're now up to 62% to 63% for that benefit. So just to remind you, when we got rid of that business, which we are working to close this quarter, we'll see a benefit of approximately 1 point on gross margin, about 0.5 point on operating margin rate and very negligible and EPS level of things falling through. So we're baking that in the guidance and since my guidance excludes that altogether. But overall, again, just attributed to the disciplined work on BCP on the productivity side as well as the sales teams being very disciplined on pricing.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Faucette, Morgan Stanley, invest in research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Faucette, Morgan Stanley, invest in research.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. First, Chuck, just wonder if you could give a little color on routing. If I'm understanding you correctly, it sounds like there may be just timing issues that made the first quarter, the October quarter, look a little bit weake
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. First, Chuck, just wonder if you could give a little color on routing. If I'm understanding you correctly, it sounds like there may be just timing issues that made the first quarter, the October quarter, look a little bit weaker. But you expect that to bounce back strongly. If you maybe give a little color and outlook how we should think about routing developing as we go through calendar '16. And then my second question is related -- somewhat related, just trying to get a sense for how we should think about security. I know that that's been a sector or segment that's been growing slower than the market. It's clearly a point of emphasis for Cisco. Just wondering how we should think about that and your [indiscernible] start to manifest themselves.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, James. Thanks. And I hope you all notice that we're actually accepting 2 questions now, I think. So good questions. On the routing side, James, you nailed it, it's a timing issue. We had good order growth. Our new routing platforms, the new platform s
componenttext: Hi, James. Thanks. And I hope you all notice that we're actually accepting 2 questions now, I think. So good questions. On the routing side, James, you nailed it, it's a timing issue. We had good order growth. Our new routing platforms, the new platform so we've introduced were up in triple digits again from an orders perspective. So we do expect that, that will bounce back. And we also have some, as I said in the earlier comments, we also have some new introductions that'll be coming out in the next week or so. So you'll see that. So we feel pretty reasonably well about our routing performance over the coming quarters. From a security perspective, I think that the team has done a great job. They've integrated the source fire malware capabilities into our firewalls and into some of our routing platforms. So they've done the hard integration work. Last quarter, we added over 2,000 new amp customers, which is advanced malware solution. We now have over 8,000 customers there. The revenue grew 7%, but our deferred grew 31% as they've continued to transition the business to more of a software and subscription. And the team's pretty confident, in the second half of the year, we can be back in the mid- to high teens from a revenue growth in security.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Brent Bracelin with Pacific Crest.
componenttext: Next question comes from Brent Bracelin with Pacific Crest.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll squeeze in 2, and we'll go from there. Chuck, for you, real quickly. APAC grew 3%.  That's the best growth reducing in 2 years. So what's driving the reversal in APAC relative to orders this quarter. And then Kelly, if you could talk a little more ab
componenttext: I'll squeeze in 2, and we'll go from there. Chuck, for you, real quickly. APAC grew 3%.  That's the best growth reducing in 2 years. So what's driving the reversal in APAC relative to orders this quarter. And then Kelly, if you could talk a little more about his shift to software subscription accelerating. Obviously, what does that mean from a revenue growth standpoint, for your Geico economically, without margins of the highest and what 9 years, what does that mean from an off margin perspective?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Take it, kelly, on the numbers, and then I'll get some color around Asia.
componenttext: Take it, kelly, on the numbers, and then I'll get some color around Asia.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. So yes, if I get the software subscription one. So this is a big focus of us, both from the acquisitions that we're doing. As you see, of those have been SaaS businesses or software businesses, as well as internal development. So we've really
componenttext: Absolutely. So yes, if I get the software subscription one. So this is a big focus of us, both from the acquisitions that we're doing. As you see, of those have been SaaS businesses or software businesses, as well as internal development. So we've really been focused on driving our software and enterprise agreements across the board. And I think you're seeing that translate on to our balance sheet that we will benefit from. When I look at the amount of our revenue coming off the balance sheet on the product side, it continues to increase, and that's how we're driving all our business units. We continue to find those and build those solutions. I'd say Meraki is a good example and our Cloud Networking Group, where basically it's 1/3 of their business gets deferred the way they sell their solution. So we're going to see more and more of that as we go forward. And we'll see the benefit of that not only on more predictable revenue but also strong margins. Operating margin is to address that. Again, we had -- it was a great quarter for operating margin. I would say, again, we talked about the benefit we're seeing on gross margin. We are being disciplined to make the right trade-offs. We're going to fluctuate always between quarters, but we are, again, driving for that profitable growth, and we are looking relentlessly for efficiencies so we can fund investments into the internal R&D and go-to-market.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brent. You indirectly asked, so I'm going to give a little color to what we see going on on Asia. It's really a mixed story from just a performance perspective. China, we have been working and investing in for years, and we've been very focused here
componenttext: Yes, Brent. You indirectly asked, so I'm going to give a little color to what we see going on on Asia. It's really a mixed story from just a performance perspective. China, we have been working and investing in for years, and we've been very focused here over the last few years. And we actually had very strong quarter in China from an orders perspective, growing over 40% this quarter. Likewise, in India, where we've been focused on a lot of country digitization efforts there with the Prime Minister and many of the ministries. And they really see the value of technology and what it can do for their country. It, too, was up over 40%. Then when you look at the rest of Asia, it was a real challenge. I believe it was negative 8% for the rest. And we did see some uncertainty creep in relative to those countries particularly who had trading relationships with China. And also we saw sort of the ripple-through affect of the China currency devaluation in predominantly or, let me say, we saw it in some of the Asian countries, in particular, because they had such trading relationships.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Keff Kvaal with Nomura Securities international.
componenttext: Next question comes from Keff Kvaal with Nomura Securities international.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to throw my 2 in as well. Chuck, maybe like giving you an opportunity to talk about the second half. It sounds like you have a few items in the fire that you're excited about. I'm cognizant of the new product introduction is usually take 2-plus q
componenttext: I wanted to throw my 2 in as well. Chuck, maybe like giving you an opportunity to talk about the second half. It sounds like you have a few items in the fire that you're excited about. I'm cognizant of the new product introduction is usually take 2-plus quarters to get going. So I imagine there's something else up your sleeve there a little bit. And Kelly, I was wondering could you help us perhaps understand a little bit in more detail the impact of the mixed shift to subscription billing how much that is costing you in terms of revenue growth and when you think that it may normalize so that the revenue growth matches the deferred revenue growth?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, so on the second half, what -- my position right now is that I feel like we're incredibly well positioned, particularly relative to the things we control in our portfolio. I've stated that I think that, that inflection point in our data center switc
componenttext: Jeff, so on the second half, what -- my position right now is that I feel like we're incredibly well positioned, particularly relative to the things we control in our portfolio. I've stated that I think that, that inflection point in our data center switching, which has been a challenge for us for many quarters, we believe that will happen in the second half of the year. We've got new product introductions coming out across security, data center as well as routing and others. So there's probably more innovation pipeline than we've seen in quite a while. I mentioned earlier that our team's pretty confident that our security business from a revenue perspective will get back into the mid-teens in the second half of the year. And frankly, we believe that some of the acquisition activity as well as the strategic partnerships could show up and begin to contribute positively perhaps sometime in the second half of the year. So we are -- I am cautiously optimistic, and I think I just feel like we'll are well positioned relative to our portfolio and what we control.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And to the second part there on how to think about the subscription software part of the business. I would say you're going to see it a couple ways. I think the amount that we see translate on to our income statement or amortized off, on the product side,
componenttext: And to the second part there on how to think about the subscription software part of the business. I would say you're going to see it a couple ways. I think the amount that we see translate on to our income statement or amortized off, on the product side, is just going to continue to accelerate that. It's been growing in a 15% to 20% every quarter, and that's just going to continue as we look forward because we are growing our SaaS businesses. We are adding to our SaaS business with acquisitions. And I'd say on the other parts of our business that hasn't traditionally been monetizing through software or licenses, we're coming up with all kinds of different offers that our customers are interested in. So I'd say, we're going to see both about business deferred grow. It'll continue to be a larger part of our products revenue growing double digits, but it's still in the 5% to 6% range as of right now on our product revenue. But that will grow in double digits going forward for many quarters.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Simon Leopold with Raymond James & Associates.
componenttext: Next question comes from Simon Leopold with Raymond James & Associates.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Victor Chu in for Simon Leopold. I'd like to ask about the trends in the Public cloud migrations. Some of the networking means, it was in the flag of a migration backup application from Enterprise data centers to public cloud as a secular headwind in
componenttext: It's Victor Chu in for Simon Leopold. I'd like to ask about the trends in the Public cloud migrations. Some of the networking means, it was in the flag of a migration backup application from Enterprise data centers to public cloud as a secular headwind in your core business. Can you speak to address any observed and how that's impacting Cisco or how you envision the next impacts your results going forward.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Victor, thank you. That's a great question. So the way we see it is our customers, we believe, are really committed to a hybrid cloud model. They see workloads that make tremendous sense to be in the public cloud. And then they are mission-critical, high-
componenttext: Victor, thank you. That's a great question. So the way we see it is our customers, we believe, are really committed to a hybrid cloud model. They see workloads that make tremendous sense to be in the public cloud. And then they are mission-critical, high-performance applications that they will continue to run in a private cloud. And we believe that out we can provide the bridge for those customers. And I think if you look at our UCS growth and you look at our next-gen data center growth, that will suggest customers are still building a data centers and still building up public cloud to take advantage of the requirements they have in high-performance applications, security, mission-critical nature. So we think it's going to be both. And we have a strategy that not only is focused on providing the best infrastructure that we can to those public and service providers who are providing web and cloud services as well as the private cloud as well as the elements of our portfolio where it makes sense to be delivered as a cloud service. We'll continue to make those moves like we have with Meraki as well as security as well as collaboration.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tim Long with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tim Long with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just head back to switching for a minute. Two-part. On the campus side, it sounds like that was pretty strong in the quarter as well. What are you seeing? Is it Wi-Fi? What are you seeing drive that? How sustainable do you think it is? And then on the dat
componenttext: Just head back to switching for a minute. Two-part. On the campus side, it sounds like that was pretty strong in the quarter as well. What are you seeing? Is it Wi-Fi? What are you seeing drive that? How sustainable do you think it is? And then on the data center side, it sounds like we're  regaining some market share there. What do you think is helping with the greater-than-industry growth rate that you're seeing currently from the likes of the 3K, the 9K and the ACI? The platform quick visit performance? What do you think is driving that?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tim, thanks for the questions. So in the campus environment, we've seen several drivers over the last few quarters. This whole move to the Internet of Things and the connectivity of more and more devices, some of which are connected hardwired, others are
componenttext: Tim, thanks for the questions. So in the campus environment, we've seen several drivers over the last few quarters. This whole move to the Internet of Things and the connectivity of more and more devices, some of which are connected hardwired, others are just increasing the wireless spectrum and the bandwidth required, the transition in the wireless access to higher speeds like 80211ac as well as the strength we've seen in our video endpoint business also translates through to, in many cases, refreshes of the networking infrastructure. And then finally, I think we see customers who are trying to beef up their security and are looking at some of the features that we can build into our campus platforms to increase their security. So those are some of the drivers that we see there that when you look at the data center, I think, frankly, the teams are just building incredible architecture. And it is built to really lower the operating costs and increase our customers' ability to implement policy in the data center in an automated way. I think they've also built incredible high-performance platforms and have given the customer the choice of both merchant as well as high-performance ASICs. And I think that the customers are seeing it. In the 9K, we added another 900 customers in the quarter. And we're now over 5,000 customers with our Nexus 9K and is the fastest-ramping data center or product we've ever had. So I think it's a testament to what the teams have built.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Jayson Noland with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Next question comes from Jayson Noland with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chuck, I wanted to ask you to comment on the storage market, given the acquisition of the EMC, the planned acquisition of EMC . Do you need to own storage IP? Or maybe the better question is that it makes sense for Cisco to own some storage IP, given the
componenttext: Chuck, I wanted to ask you to comment on the storage market, given the acquisition of the EMC, the planned acquisition of EMC . Do you need to own storage IP? Or maybe the better question is that it makes sense for Cisco to own some storage IP, given the pace of innovation and storage and your success with UCS? Or is status quo the best plan forward from here?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jayson. Thanks for the question. So as we look at the future and we look across our entire portfolio, candidly, we are assessing what our customers need from us and what solutions they'd like to see from us. And then we will leverage R&D, we'll lever
componenttext: Yes, Jayson. Thanks for the question. So as we look at the future and we look across our entire portfolio, candidly, we are assessing what our customers need from us and what solutions they'd like to see from us. And then we will leverage R&D, we'll leverage M&A, we'll leverage codevelopment, we'll leverage strategic partnerships. And we'll move on any one of those fronts across any area that we need to fulfill the solutions that our customers are looking for. Specifically the area you asked about to date, partnering strategy has been sufficient for what we need. But you can assume that we're constantly looking at that and other areas and what we need to add to our portfolio, and then we determine whether we're going to do with the acquisition or partnership. But our partnership so far with IBM, Hitachi, EMC, NetApp, et cetera, have been very positive for us, as you can see through our UCS ramp over the years.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Paul Silverstein with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Next question comes from Paul Silverstein with Cowen and Company.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: chuck, you mentioned that your largest [indiscernible] customers were up by over 20% again this quarter. It implies that's been historical trend, but that's the question. What has been the historical trend? Is that the right number? If you can give us ins
componenttext: chuck, you mentioned that your largest [indiscernible] customers were up by over 20% again this quarter. It implies that's been historical trend, but that's the question. What has been the historical trend? Is that the right number? If you can give us insight on that. And then I've got a question about OpEx as a percentage of revenue going forward for Kelly, what we should expect. Is there more you could do in terms of further improvement and finally just quickly, employee turnover both desirable and common undesirable. Can you update us on that?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, Paul. Now you're getting carried away. I'm just kidding. So let me take the first one on the web scale side. I think I've talked about it in various forums that we really, in the last 12 to 15 months, I think, really began to embark on building
componenttext: All right, Paul. Now you're getting carried away. I'm just kidding. So let me take the first one on the web scale side. I think I've talked about it in various forums that we really, in the last 12 to 15 months, I think, really began to embark on building products and working with the web scale players in a very unique way to make sure that our products really reflected the things that are important to them. So we've only talked about our growth there for the last couple of quarters. We haven't really focused on it for a while, but I'll tell you that it's really the last 1.5 years when we really got, I think, serious with them about building the solutions that they're really looking for. And I think that the growth that we're seeing right now is as well as some of the codevelopment that you're going to see coming out is reflective of that focus. Kelly, on the OpEx?

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the OpEx. So on the OpEx, Paul, we are obviously driving that hard and managing it well. I will say, though, interest of full disclosure. As you expect, much of the FX headwinds on the top line we are benefiting from on the OpEx side as well right
componenttext: Yes, on the OpEx. So on the OpEx, Paul, we are obviously driving that hard and managing it well. I will say, though, interest of full disclosure. As you expect, much of the FX headwinds on the top line we are benefiting from on the OpEx side as well right? So we're balancing both of those things and for this quarter with a couple of hundred million dollars. So I'd say that we will make the trade-off on OpEx to balance what the business is facing on margins in top line everything else. But we are -- because we are very focused on where we are putting those investment dollars to make sure we are putting the R&D dollars in where the innovation is. So I think what you can take away is the OpEx, as a percentage, might change as currency changes. But we will manage within there very tightly and disciplined in terms of balancing it with the rest of the business.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from George Notter with Jefferies.
componenttext: Next question comes from George Notter with Jefferies.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Earlier you gave a customer account number on the Nexus 9000. I guess I was just curious about the ACI version of that product. It's a number, I think, you've given in the past. But also I wanted to take out into currency a little bit more. Kelly, I think
componenttext: Earlier you gave a customer account number on the Nexus 9000. I guess I was just curious about the ACI version of that product. It's a number, I think, you've given in the past. But also I wanted to take out into currency a little bit more. Kelly, I think you gave a nice comment on the translation impact on currency. And I think there were some comments about Asia with a transactional impact as well. But I just to get your numbers historically, of the packages, get a sense of the BRIC countries some of the like Brazil, Russia, where you had a real severe impact, you've seen a big comparison for a period of time now. I guess I'm wondering have you hit kind of the bottom in some of the areas of the world? And the foreign exchange currency impact starts to kind of come off over time. So how big is the impact and what does it come off is the question.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. So what I was referencing -- so again, I think, for sure, the impact that we can see on the countries where we sell in local currency, which is only a few countries, is about 2 points, right? So for all the other countries, including the emergin
componenttext: Yes, yes. So what I was referencing -- so again, I think, for sure, the impact that we can see on the countries where we sell in local currency, which is only a few countries, is about 2 points, right? So for all the other countries, including the emerging markets and Europe, it's hard for us, because we sell in dollars, to really quantify the impact, but there is certainly an impact on-demand. You're right about Brazil and Russia. They have been challenged for some time. I think the growth in our emerging being up 11% is largely driven by the strength of India and Mexico, which have been very strong for the last 5 quarters. And now adding on to that, China was having broad-based strength is really driving that back up. If I back out those -- the BRIC countries, right, the rest of the emerging markets are, I would say, not really growing. They're flattish to up to 3% when I exclude the BRIC and countries because they are feeling the impact, I would say, of currency. And I think we're still the uncertainty with if the U.S. rate is interest rates, what that will further due to U.S. dollar strength. So it's tough to have a full view quantification of it, but we do think while there is the right state where they are today, it might get a little easier of a headwind as we move forward through the year. Now it's just I think the answer to the and the parts are feeling as well as in interest rates uncertainty going forward.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: And George, let me circle back to the first question you asked on the ACI. I think you asked the ACI version of the 9K. What I think we're focused right now as actually looking at customers who are deploying ACI in general. So let me give you that data po
componenttext: And George, let me circle back to the first question you asked on the ACI. I think you asked the ACI version of the 9K. What I think we're focused right now as actually looking at customers who are deploying ACI in general. So let me give you that data point. We had a 200 more APIC customers, which are those customers that are deploying a policy engine that takes advantage of ACI. And we're over 1,100 customers that have the APIC. So that's a number that I think you are looking for.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, I want to thank everyone for spending time with us today. And I think I will close by highlighting 3 things. The first, I really believe that we are executing incredibly well in a somewhat challenging market. We had the second as we had very
componenttext: First of all, I want to thank everyone for spending time with us today. And I think I will close by highlighting 3 things. The first, I really believe that we are executing incredibly well in a somewhat challenging market. We had the second as we had very strong execution in our results in Q1. We have solid growth for Q2, and we feel like we're very well positioned again for the second half of the year. The third is we will continue to move very fast in positioning ourselves for future growth opportunities. And I feel very good about how we're positioned in general. So to give us any time with us today and look forward to talking to many of you soon.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks. Cisco's next quarterly call, which will reflect our FY '16 quarter results, will be on Wednesday, February 10, 2016, at 1:30 p.m. Pacific, 4:30 p.m, Easter. Again, that I might've Regulation FD, this policy to not comment on its financial g
componenttext: Great. Thanks. Cisco's next quarterly call, which will reflect our FY '16 quarter results, will be on Wednesday, February 10, 2016, at 1:30 p.m. Pacific, 4:30 p.m, Easter. Again, that I might've Regulation FD, this policy to not comment on its financial guidance for the quarter and was is it public disclosure. We'll now close the call. Have a further questions, please contact back Cisco higher department. Thank you for joining us today.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Cisco Systems' First Quarter and Fiscal Year 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. At the request of Cisco Systems, today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect. Now I would like to introduce Melissa Selcher,
componenttext: Welcome to Cisco Systems' First Quarter and Fiscal Year 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. At the request of Cisco Systems, today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect. Now I would like to introduce Melissa Selcher, Vice President of Corporate Communication and Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kim. Welcome, everyone, to Cisco's First Quarter FY '16 Quarterly Conference Call. This is Melissa Selcher, and I'm joined by Chuck Robbins, our CEO; and Kelly Kramer, our CFO. By now, you should've seen our earnings release. A corresponding web
componenttext:
Thanks, Kim. Welcome, everyone, to Cisco's First Quarter FY '16 Quarterly Conference Call. This is Melissa Selcher, and I'm joined by Chuck Robbins, our CEO; and Kelly Kramer, our CFO. 
By now, you should've seen our earnings release. A corresponding webcast with slides, including supplemental information, will be available on our website in the Investor Relations section following the call.
Income statements, full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information, balance sheet, cash flow statements and other financial information can also be found on the Financial Information section of our Investor Relations website. 
Throughout this conference call, we'll be referencing both GAAP and non-GAAP financial results and will discuss product results in terms of revenue and geographic and customer results in terms of product orders unless stated otherwise. All comparisons throughout this call will be on a year-over-year basis, unless stated otherwise. 
The matters we'll be discussing today include forward-looking statements, including the guidance we provided for the second quarter.  They are subject to the risks and uncertainties that we discussed in detail in our documents filed with the SEC, specifically the most recent report on the Form 10-K, which identifies important risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements. 
With respect to guidance, please also see the slides and press release that accompany this call for further details.  As a reminder, Cisco will not comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it's done through an explicit public disclosure. 
I'll now turn it over to Chuck.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mel. So Q1 was a very strong quarter across the board. We grew our revenue 4% and delivered non-GAAP earnings per share growth of 9%. We delivered very strong non-GAAP gross margins, and our non-GAAP operating margin was the best we've seen in ove
componenttext:
Thanks, Mel. So Q1 was a very strong quarter across the board. We grew our revenue 4% and delivered non-GAAP earnings per share growth of 9%. We delivered very strong non-GAAP gross margins, and our non-GAAP operating margin was the best we've seen in over 9 years. 
I recognize that our Q2 guidance was -- that we just provided is below what the market had expected. In Q1, we saw lower-than-expected order growth, driven largely by uncertainty for macro and currency impacts, primarily outside the U.S. Despite these headwinds, I believe we are executing incredibly well in a challenging environment. 
Let me tell you simply how I see it. We had a great quarter, guided to solid growth in Q2 and feel good about our momentum and how we are positioned for the second half of the year. 
As I look at the big picture, I'm extremely pleased with the speed with which our teams are executing. We have a clear strategy and are confident that we are making the right transitions in our business, investing where we need to for future growth, profitability and market leadership. Specifically, we are accelerating our ability to deliver on the growth opportunities in front of us. We are driving internal innovation at a record pace. So far, in FY '16, we're seeing 25% increase in major new product introductions, and 3 of our internal startups brought solutions to market this quarter working with our key customers. These startups are bringing incredible technology from concept to delivery in under 12 months. Stay tuned next week for announcements around an additional project that we codeveloped with one of the world's largest web scale players. 
In this quarter alone, we closed 3 acquisitions, recently announced 4 new acquisitions and formed 3 new strategic partnerships. Partners like Apple, Inspur and Ericsson see Cisco as the market leader they want to work with to move faster and drive greater value to customers and the market. 
I believe we will see several points of growth from these partnerships over the next few years.
We are also aggressively driving our cloud businesses. We've always had a hybrid cloud strategy, and it is increasingly clear that every one of our customers want both public and private cloud capabilities in a hybrid cloud. 
On the public cloud side, Cisco is a leading provider of infrastructure to the web scale and SP customers as they build out their public cloud infrastructure as just one data point. Our business with the largest web scale players grew over 20% again this quarter. 
Within the enterprise, we are winning in private cloud and are focused on automating and driving public cloud economics across our customers' entire infrastructure. We saw this opportunity to drive 24% growth in UCS, and our next-generation data center switching portfolio, which is our 3K, 9K and ACI, is now at a $2 billion run rate, with over $500 million in revenue this quarter, growing over 140% year-over-year, with sequential growth of 26%. This performance is much stronger than that of our competitors who claim they are outpacing and outperforming us. 
And our own cloud services continue to grow well. WebEx, one of the largest enterprise SaaS applications in the world, grew revenue over 23% this quarter, and we continue to move more of our portfolio to cloud-based delivery models. 
As we deliver more of our portfolio and software and cloud models, we are driving consistent double-digit growth and deferred revenue. We saw software and subscription product deferred revenue up 36%. Security deferred revenue grew 31% as we sell next-generation firewall and threat defense software to our over 200,000 firewall customers. 
Our collaboration deferred revenue grew 18%, and our Meraki cloud networking business, where we deliver networking as-a-service, grew revenue over 60%. While we still have work to do across our portfolio, I'm incredibly pleased with our continued focus and speed of execution. We will continue to make the necessary strategic moves to drive our success.
Over the last quarter, I've spent hundreds of hours with our customers and partners around the world, and they have reaffirmed my confidence in our ability to execute against the opportunity in front of us. 
While the market continues to move at an accelerated pace, our customers know they must move with speed as they embark on their digital transitions. It's clear to me that they also understand the central and critical role that the network plays in that transition. And they are looking to us to be a strategic partner to drive their growth and build their digital organization, cities and countries. 
We are doing the right things to capitalize on this opportunity, and as I told our teams this past week, I have never been more optimistic. 
Now I'll turn it over to Kelly to walk through more details on our financials.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck. I am pleased with our execution on our financial strategy of delivering profitable growth, managing our portfolio and strategic investments and delivering shareholder value. Starting with our first pillar of delivering profitable growth.
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck. I am pleased with our execution on our financial strategy of delivering profitable growth, managing our portfolio and strategic investments and delivering shareholder value. 
Starting with our first pillar of delivering profitable growth. We saw good top line growth in Q1 with $12.7 billion and total revenue up 4%. Product revenue grew 4%, with solid growth in switching, data center, wireless, security and collaborations. More specifically, in Q1, switching grew 5%. In addition to the 3K, 9K and ACI momentum of over 140%, we continue to see strength in the Catalyst business. 
Data Center grew 24%, demonstrating our continued market leadership. Wireless grew 7%, driven by the Meraki business. Security was up 7%, with deferred revenue growth of 31%. And collaboration grew 17%, with deferred revenue up 18%.  In total, deferred revenue had solid double-digit growth of 10%, with products deferred revenue up 16% and services up 7%. 
Product deferred revenue, driven by our subscription and software businesses, grew 36%. We do see the transition to subscription revenue accelerating, as I mentioned in the last earnings call. 
We did see routing decline 8%. We do expect routing revenue to return to growth due to timing of some large deals we saw in Q1. Services revenue grew 1%, largely driven by weakness in Service Provider. Product orders grew 3% with a book-to-bill below 1, which is in line with our typical Q1s but slightly lighter than we had expected. 
Looking at our geographies, which is a primary way we run our business, Americas grew 1%, EMEA grew 3% and APJC was up 9%. Total emerging markets grew a very solid 11%, with the BRICS plus Mexico accelerating to 21% growth. 
In terms of customer segment, Service Provider grew 6%. Enterprise declined 3% based on the uncertainty from macro challenges, consistent with what others are seeing. Commercial grew 7%, which signals to us the broad strength of our portfolio. Public Sector was flat. 
From a profitability perspective, we delivered record non-GAAP EPS of $0.59, up 9%. GAAP EPS was $0.48. Q1 non-GAAP net income was a record $3 billion, up 8%. GAAP net income was $2.4 billion. 
We drove the strong profitability with discipline and rigor on gross margins and operating expense. Non-GAAP gross margin was 63.2%, with non-GAAP product gross margin of 62.3% and non-GAAP service gross margin of 66.2%. 
Non-GAAP operating expenses were well-controlled at 32.7% of revenue, and non-GAAP operating margin expanded to 30.5%. 
We are ensuring we make the right investment and divestment decisions through disciplined portfolio management. 
Moving on to the second pillar of our financial strategy, which is the work we are doing to manage our portfolio and strategic investments to fuel our key long-term growth areas such as cloud, data center, software, services and security. 
We've been very active from an M&A perspective on aligning our investments to key growth areas. We closed 3 acquisitions in Q1 with OpenDNS and Pawaa in software and security and MaintenanceNet in services. We also announced the acquisitions of Portcullis and Lancope in security, ParStream in data and analytics and 1 Mainstream in cloud-based video. These moves are consistent with our strategy of increasing the investment of our innovation and R&D efforts to our growth areas. 
Moving on to our third pillar, delivering shareholder value. In Q1, we increased operating cash flow 11% to $2.8 billion. Total cash, cash equivalents and investments at the end of Q1 were $59.1 billion, with $5 billion available in the U.S. And we returned $2.3 billion to shareholders, comprised of $1.2 billion of share repurchases and $1.1 billion of dividends. The total share returned to shareholders represents a return of 91% of our free cash flow, more than consistent with our commitment to shareholders of returning a minimum of 50% of our free cash flow annually. 
Overall, Q1 was a strong quarter. As you review the financials, you see good top line growth, record profitability and operating leverage, a very strong balance sheet with growth in deferred revenue and strong cash generation. We executed well, consistent with our business and financial strategy. 
Now let me reiterate the guidance we provided in the press release for the second quarter of fiscal year '16. This guidance includes the type of forward-looking information that Mel referred to earlier. As a reminder, in Q4, we announced an agreement to sell that client premises equipment portion of our SP Video connected devices business to Technicolor. The transaction is currently going through regulatory approval, and we are working to close it during the second quarter. In order to provide a clear view of our continuing expected financial performance, we have normalized our second quarter guidance to exclude the CPE business for both Q2 fiscal year '16 and Q2 fiscal year '15. We've provided historical financial information for the CPE business in the slides that accompany this call. 
So now on to our Q2 guidance. We are executing very well in a challenging global environment but did see the macro challenges driving uncertainty that impacted our Q1 order growth. As a result, the guidance for Q2, excluding the CPE businesses, is as follows: We expect revenue to be in the range of 0% to 2% year-over-year; we anticipate non-GAAP gross margin rate to be in the range of 62% to 63%; the non-GAAP operating margin rate is expected to be in the range of 28.5% to 29.5%; and the non-GAAP tax provision rate is expected to be 23%. 
The tax rate does not include any impact of the reinstatement of the federal R&D tax credit. If the R&D tax credit is reinstated, we would reflect that benefit in our effective tax rate. 
Non-GAAP earnings per share is expected to range from $0.53 to $0.55. We anticipate our GAAP EPS to be lower than the non-GAAP EPS by $0.10 to $0.14. Further details related to this range are included in the slides and press release that accompany this call. 
I'll now turn it back to Chuck to summarize the call.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kelly. So as I look back at the last 90 days in my first quarter, I am more optimistic than ever about Cisco's future. Yes, the guidance we just gave for Q2 is lower than what the market had expected, and I don't take that lightly. But for me, n
componenttext:
Thanks, Kelly. So as I look back at the last 90 days in my first quarter, I am more optimistic than ever about Cisco's future. 
Yes, the guidance we just gave for Q2 is lower than what the market had expected, and I don't take that lightly. But for me, nothing has changed in how I feel about the business. We are moving incredibly fast and doing all the right things to drive our growth and strategic relevance.  We expect the result of these moves will start showing up in the coming quarters. 
Every one of our customers, established industry leaders and disruptive challengers, is focused on how they manage, automate and secure the explosion of connections and data across their digital organization. Our portfolio has never been stronger, more relevant and more strategic. And we're hearing this directly from our customers and our partners. The opportunity is ours to capitalize on. 
We have a clear vision and strategy and are well very well. We are driving internal innovation at a record pace, acquiring strategic assets, codeveloping with our customers and building a new set of strategic partnerships. I believe our speed and execution are truly differentiating us in the market, and we've just begun to scratch the surface of what's possible. 
And Mel, I'll turn it back to you for questions.

headline: Cisco Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Kim. Let's open the line for questions. I'd like to remind all analysts to please ask one question.
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Kim. Let's open the line for questions. I'd like to remind all analysts to please ask one question.

componenttext: So Chuck, my question is around -- we had done independent checks and had noted near-term weakness in U.S. Enterprise. Like to get your qualitative color. I know you work very closely with the sales teams and also with some of your bigger customers.
